title: Correlating Cryogenic Ptychography and EELS to Disentangle Structural and Electronic Components of a Metal-Insulator Transition in NdNiO3
content: Metal-insulator transitions (MITs) in quantum materials have attracted great interest both for potential applications in areas such as neuromorphic computing, as well as for efforts to trace their physical origin to the interplay between lattice, electronic and spin degree of freedom [1]. While MITs are usually accompanied by a structural transition, a key question in many systems is whether the transition is electronically or structurally driven and – particularly for device applications where switching speeds are critical – whether the transitions can be decoupled [2]. One such heavily-studied model system with concurrent structural and electronic transition is the rare-earth nickelate perovskites, in which the MIT is thought to be strongly dependent on structural parameters such as bond angle [3]. Here, we focus on NdNiO3, which in bulk exhibits a high-temperature metallic orthorhombic phase that transitions to a monoclinic insulator upon cooling below the metal-insulator transition temperature TMI ∼205 K [4]. It has been proposed that the transition is accompanied by electronic charge disproportionation on the nickel sites [4]. Recent advances in the growth of high quality thin-films of nickelates offer a potential opportunity to explore possible suppression of the structural transition using the effects of confinement in the ultra-thin limit [5]. Successful fabrication of membrane geometry of these high-quality thin films now provides a direct way of characterizing plan-view and cross-sectional orientation providing multiscale information not easily unattainable in ultra-thin films otherwise [6].
